p.m: \text{If Mary fails her classes, then she cannot graduate.}

statement.p:
Write the statement in formal logic:
\mathbin{\sim} p\rightarrow q
q\rightarrow p
p\rightarrow \mathbin{\sim} q
p\rightarrow q

Negate the logic:
\mathbin{\sim} p\wedge \mathbin{\sim} q
\mathbin{\sim} p\wedge q
p\wedge q
\mathbin{\sim} p\vee \mathbin{\sim} q

Rewrite the negated logic in English
Mary does not fail her classes or she cannot graduate
Mary does not fail her classes and she cannot graduate
Mary does not fail her classes and she can graduate
Mary fails her classes and she can graduate

p.m: \text{Billy and Bob are applying for the same job, but only one can succeed.}

statement.p:
Choose the correct statement:
\mathbin{\sim} (p\wedge q)
\mathbin{\sim} (p\vee q)
p\vee q
p\wedge q

static.solution:
\text{Billy and Bob are applying for the same job, but only one can succeed.}
\text{p: Billy gets the job}
\text{q: Bob gets the job}
First, translate the statement into formal logic.
In this statement, p can be true, xor q can be true, or neither can be true. The key here is that while either one can succeed, there is no guarantee of success. The expression is then equal to
\mathbin{\sim} (p\wedge q)
Now, negate the statement.
\mathbin{\sim} ( \mathbin{\sim} (p\wedge q))
\equiv \mathbin{\sim} \mathbin{\sim} (p\wedge q)
\equiv p\wedge q
The answer is then
p\wedge q
As an extra exercise, what would this statement translate to in English?
